descriptions.content:
The marker ལ་ (and its variant ར་) take on the case functions of the locative (with or without movement) and dative. It also functions as adverbial suffix and marker of object incorporation. The latter serves to express the outcome or the effect of a transformation produced by the verbal action.[1] All these different meanings may be translated into English by “to,” “in,” or “at,” or may remain untranslated as the examples below illustrate.

Examples in the locative:

  • རྒྱ་གར་ལ་འགྲོ་ “To go to India”
  • རྡོ་རྗེ་གླིང་ལ་སྡོད་ “To live in Darjeeling”

Examples in the dative:

  • བྱིས་པ་དག་ལ་སྒྲུང་བཤད་ “To tell a story to the children”
  • བྱིས་པ་རྩེད་མོ་ལ་དགའ་ “The children like the game.” (Literally: “They have pleasure in the game.”)

Example of object incorporation:

  • སོལ་བར་གཏོང་ “To turn into charcoal,” “to carbonize”

Example of adverbial use:

  • མཁྱོགས་པོར་ “Quickly,” “at speed”

The marker ལ་ also has connective functions, and may serve as a connective. It can therefore be translated by “and” or “at the time.” It may also be used to form purpose clauses.

In the latter case, the marker ལ་ is often associated with the nominalizer པ་ (or its variant བ་): པར་, in which case it is attached directly to the verb.

  • ཤོག་ལ་ལྟོས་ཤིག “Come and look.”
  • གསལ་ལ་ཟླུམ་པའི་ཟླ་བ་ “The bright (and) round moon”
  • བོད་སྨན་སློབ་པར་གཏོང་ “To send (someone) to study Tibetan medicine”
  • ཆང་ཉོར་ (ཉོ་བར་) ཕྱིན་ “To go to buy chang”

And finally, the marker ལ་ serves as an expressive particle when it is placed after an adjective at the end of a phrase:

  • སྐྱིད་པ་ལ། “How pleasant!”
  • སྙིང་རྗེ་བ་ལ། “How pretty!”

 

[1] From a syntactic point of view, the case marker usually integrates or incorporates the object into the verb and thus creates a compound verb. This function of object incorporation is called དེ་ཉིད་ in traditional grammars.
